docs.abstract: Tyler Kepner On Baseball column examines the Kansas City Royal's bullpen and notes that many do not have extensive professional careers, but did play in college; remarks that Royal's pitcher Brandon Finnegan is first player to appear in College World Series and MLB World Series in same year.

docs.snippet: WINDT--Robert. He was born April 27, 1920 and died October 24, 2014. Robert Stanley Windt was bred in Brooklyn. He was a graduate of New Utrecht High School and a life-long baseball fan having seen the Dodgers play at Ebbets Field. He joined the A...
docs.lead_paragraph: WINDT--Robert. He was born April 27, 1920 and died October 24, 2014. Robert Stanley Windt was bred in Brooklyn. He was a graduate of New Utrecht High School and a life-long baseball fan having seen the Dodgers play at Ebbets Field. He joined the Army for World War II becoming a carburation expert and B-29 Bomber instructor. At the end of the War, he returned home to live with his mother and start a career in public relations working for such companies as CBS, Mountain Valley Water, Dumont Television, Fairchild Publications, Pepsi Cola, Royal Crown Cola, Seagram's and STP Motor Oil. He retired from the profession when he and his two partners sold their ownership of Bebidas, a Spanish language beverage industry magazine. Uncle Bob, as he was known, was a loving, son, brother, uncle, great-uncle and great-great-uncle with a story or three at every family gathering. He will be missed by his family and friends. At the request of the family, donations in his memory can be made to the List Family Fund for Jewish Culture in Memory of Lawrence List at the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue (131 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201). To use Uncle Bob's favorite word - he had a "Fabulous" life. Bobye, Deborah and Mali List.

Uncle Bob, as he was known, was a loving, son, brother, uncle, great-uncle and great-great-uncle with a story or three at every family gathering. He will be missed by his family and friends. At the request of the family, donations in his memory can be made to the List Family Fund for Jewish Culture in Memory of Lawrence List at the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue (131 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201).
